tutorial.title: Waiting in JS
tutorial.descriptionContent: Learn what Promises are in JS and how to handle when they are fulfilled or rejected

lessons.title: What is a promise
lessons.interactiveContent:
JS Promises are objects that represent the outcome of an asynchronous operation.

A JS promise is like a real-life promise. It can be fulfilled or rejected. When we're waiting to know the result, the promise is pending.

lessons.title: Constructing a Promise Object
lessons.interactiveContent:
To create a new Promise object, we use the new keyword and the Promise constructor method. The constructor takes a function as a parameter.

Make sure to pick new, followed by Promise.

lessons.title: The Promise Constructor Parameter
lessons.interactiveContent:
The passed-in function itself takes two parameters. The first is resolve and the second is reject.

Make sure to pick resolve, followed by reject.

lessons.title: Resolving/Rejecting a Promise
lessons.interactiveContent:
When a promise is fulfilled, we say the promise is resolved. When the promise fails, it's rejected.

Make sure to pick resolve, followed by reject.

lessons.title: Resolving a Promise in action
lessons.interactiveContent:
The promise constructor passes its own resolve and reject functions into the constructor.

If the promise is fulfilled, the resolve function changes the promise status from pending to fulfilled. The resolve function takes one argument.

Make sure to pick resolve.

lessons.title: Rejecting a Promise in action
lessons.interactiveContent:
Similar to the resolve function, the reject function takes one argument. This argument is generally a reason for the output rejection or an error.

Make sure to pick reject.

lessons.title: Promise Settlement
lessons.interactiveContent:
The initial state of any promise is pending. But, we know that it will finish executing at any certain point in time.

In this example, the promise will be resolved because there is enough stock of cheesecake in the dessertStock object.

Make sure to pick resolve, followed by reject.

lessons.title: Question: What is a promise?
lessons.interactiveContent:
What is a JS promise?

A JS object that represents the outcome of an async operationA JS object that resolves all pending code

A JS object that represents the outcome of an async operation.

lessons.title: Question: Constructing a Promise Object
lessons.interactiveContent:
What are the parameters passed to the Promise constructor method?

resolve, rejectpending, resolve, reject

resolve, reject.

lessons.title: Example: Constructing a Promise Object
lessons.interactiveContent:
Assign an empty promise constructor method to the purchasePromise variable.

Make sure to pick new followed by Promise and then resolve, reject.

lessons.title: Example: Resolving a Promise in action
lessons.interactiveContent:
Will the promise in the code below resolve or reject?

resolvereject

Make sure to pick resolve.

lessons.title: Example: Rejecting a Promise in action
lessons.interactiveContent:
Will the promise resolve or reject?

rejectresolve

Make sure to pick reject.

lessons.title: Question: Promise Settlement
lessons.interactiveContent:
What's the default status of the promise before it's rejected or resolved?

pendingundefined

Make sure to pick pending.

lessons.title: Intro
lessons.interactiveContent:
Once a promise is resolved, we need to handle the resolved or rejected data.

Let's explore how to handle these returned promise objects!

lessons.title: Handling Fulfilled Promises
lessons.interactiveContent:
If a promise is fulfilled, the .then method helps us handle the result of the promise.

We use .then to include actions for when the promise is no longer in the pending state.

Make sure to pick .then.

lessons.title: The `.then` method
lessons.interactiveContent:
We use the .then method on the returned promise object. The first parameter for the .then method is the onResolved parameter.

The onResolved is the value returned when the promise resolves. We can give it any name, onResolved is an example.

Make sure to pick ., followed by then, and finally onResolved.

lessons.title: Tidying Up The Code
lessons.interactiveContent:
To avoid overcomplicated code in promises, we can create a function to handle the success value.

And pass the function to the .then method attached to the makeOrder variable.

Make sure to pick handleSuccess, followed by handleSuccess.

lessons.title: The `.catch` method
lessons.interactiveContent:
What if the promise is not fulfilled? The .then method won't execute and we'll get an uncaught error.

To sort this out, we can use the .catch method to handle errors when the promise is rejected.

Make sure to pick ., followed by catch.

lessons.title: Chaining Multiple Promises
lessons.interactiveContent:
Sometimes, we need to handle data in a sequential manner. To do so, we can chain .then methods.

We can chain as many .then methods as we want. This allows us to process promise objects returned from other promise objects.

Make sure to pick .then, followed by .then.

lessons.title: Chaining Multiple Promises 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Here, we check if a cheesecake is available. If true, we then check if the price is within the budget limits.

The second promise checkPrice depends on the result value from the first promise.

Make sure to pick handleIsAvailable, followed by handleCheckPrice.

lessons.title: Adding `catch` to the chain.
lessons.interactiveContent:
Even if we chain many .then methods, we can still add the .catch method to handle any rejections.

Here, the promise will be rejected because the sponge cake is not available.

Make sure to pick .then, followed by .then, and finally .catch.

lessons.title: Question: the `then` method
lessons.interactiveContent:
What's the purpose of the .then method?

It determines the next step on what to do with the returned value of the promise objectIt creates multiple promises at once

It determines the next step on what to do with the returned value of the promise object.

lessons.title: Example: the `then` method
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code the function passed as a parameter in the .then method to print the resolved value.

Make sure to pick checkWeather followed by . and then then, resolvedValue.

lessons.title: Question: the `catch` method
lessons.interactiveContent:
What's the functionality of the catch method?

It handles rejections or errors resulting from a promiseIt handles all reference errors thrown by JavaScript

It handles rejections or errors resulting from a promise.

lessons.title: Example: the `catch` method
lessons.interactiveContent:
For this example, handle the rejected promise and print the reason for the rejection.

Make sure to pick ., followed by catch, and finally console.log(error).

lessons.title: Example: Chaining Multiple Promises
lessons.interactiveContent:
How many promises are chained to the goToTheMall promise?

23

Make sure to pick 2.

lessons.title: Example: Chaining Multiple Promises 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Complete the .then chain on the goToMall promise.

Make sure to pick goToTheMall, followed by handleSelectShoes, and finally handlePurchaseShoes.

lessons.title: Example: Adding `catch` to the chain
lessons.interactiveContent:
Handle the rejection of the serveFood promise.

Make sure to pick .catch, followed by handleServeFood.

lessons.title: The async/await Syntax
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can also handle asynchronous operations with async/await. This is a new syntax introduced with ES8.

The async/await syntax makes writing and reading asynchronous code easy. And, internally, it uses the JS promises that we already know!

lessons.title: The async keyword
lessons.interactiveContent:
To inform JavaScript that we are writing an asynchronous function, we add the async keyword before the function keyword.

Async functions always return promise objects. We'll then write more code to handle these objects.

Make sure to pick async.

lessons.title: The await keyword
lessons.interactiveContent:
We use the await keyword inside an async function. await waits for the promise to be resolved.

Here, await pauses the execution of our async code inside the asyncFunction until traditionalPromise is resolved.

Make sure to pick await.

lessons.title: Native Way to handle Promises
lessons.interactiveContent:
The async/await syntax allows us to have more readable code and is usually shorter than a traditional promise.

The code below contains multiple traditional JS promises that are dependent on one another.

Make sure to pick handleWaterReadyCheck, followed by handlePrepareDrink.

lessons.title: The async/await way to handle promises
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can make this code shorter and more readable with the async/await syntax. Our code even looks similar to synchronous code.

Scroll to the bottom of the code and include the async and await keywords.

Make sure to pick async followed by await and then await, await.

lessons.title: try/catch
lessons.interactiveContent:
By now, we have seen how to handle promises that always resolve. But what happens with promises that fail?

To handle rejections, we use the try-catch syntax. First, the code tries to run and if it fails, the error is caught.

Make sure to pick try, followed by catch.

lessons.title: Question: The async/await syntax
lessons.interactiveContent:
What's the main advantage of using the async/await syntax?

It helps make asynchronous code easier to read and writeIt performs faster than native and traditional JS promises

It helps make asynchronous code easier to read and write.

lessons.title: Question: The async keyword
lessons.interactiveContent:
How do we inform the JavaScript engine that a certain function is async?

By adding the async keyword before the function declarationBy providing a parameter to the function called async

By adding the async keyword before the function declaration.

lessons.title: Example: The await keyword
lessons.interactiveContent:
Await the value resulting from the obtainGrade promise and print it in the console.

Make sure to pick await, followed by obtainGrade, and finally value.

lessons.title: Example: The async keyword
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code an asynchronous function that prints the message Hello Developers!.

Make sure to type async function.

lessons.title: Question: Native way to handle promises
lessons.interactiveContent:
Why is the async/await syntax usually easier to read than the native JS promise?

Because it writes the code in a style similar to synchronous codeBecause it has more features that allow for more readability and debugging

Because it writes the code in a style similar to synchronous code.

lessons.title: Example: The async/await way to promises
lessons.interactiveContent:
Complete the handlePromise function to print all the resolved messages from the three promises in the code below.

Make sure to pick async followed by await and then await, await.

lessons.title: Example: try/catch
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which result will execute?

The code in the catch blockThe code in the try block

The code in the catch block.

lessons.title: Example: try/catch 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Write a try/catch block to handle success and failure on the checkGasCost promise.

Make sure to pick try followed by await and then checkGasCost, result, catch, error.
